body: Do we have to have KStreamAggregate and KStreamWindowAggregate? Can we simply use UnlimitedWindow internally and make unwindowed aggregates a syntax sugar?
@ymatsuda Originally I was trying to do that, but realized it may be better to not use a RocksWindowStore for KStreamAggregate (not windowed), hence not just a syntax sugar. What do you think?
got it.

@becketqin : Thanks for finding the issue and providing the patch. The patch doesn't seem to fix the issue completely though. The problem that I am seeing is that when there is only 1 replica in ISR, the only time that we will update HW is when a new message is appended. So, if no new message is appended and we roll a log segment, HW will stay on the old segment. Now, if a new fetch request comes in with log end offset, log.fetch() will return the new segment in LogOffsetMetadata. Then, in DelayedFetch.tryComplete(), since the fetch offset is not on the same segment as HW (even though offset is the same), we will complete the fetch request immediately and therefore incorrectly ignore max wait time.
LGTM

@ismael @ewencp Trivial change; ran fix here:
http://confluent-kafka-branch-builder-system-test-results.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/2016-02-05--001.1454651979--confluentinc--increment-kafkatest-version-0.9.0--bbc7053/report.html

Thanks @granders. Maybe we should add a comment in gradle.properties pointing out that we also need to update this file when bumping the version?

In trunk, could we extract the version from gradle.properties to avoid the issue altogether?
LGTM, thanks @granthenke!
LGTM.

@junrao Thanks for the review. Your comments are addressed. 
I have created separate tickets for integration test. I am working on the upgrade doc now and will update it later.

Also, would it be more intuitive for LogOffsetMetadata.precede to just check the offset? I was thinking that another way to fix this is to leave LogOffsetMetadata.precede() as it is. In DelayedFetch.tryComplete(), we first check if the offset in the two LogOffsetMetadata are equal. If so, we just continue with case D. Otherwise, we will go through the rest of the logic. We can also try to keep HW always on the latest segment. However, this will need some callback logic in Log when a new log is rolled.

@ijuma That's a good point, it would be nice not to duplicate in this way - the tricky part about extracting from `gradle.properties` dynamically is that `kafkatest` can be, and is also used as a standalone package which can be referenced by other projects (primarily for reusing services), and `gradle.properties` won't be available in that context.
I see, fair enough.
Follow up from https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/878
LGTM
LGTM. An observation: after we branch we no longer want to update `kafka-merge-pr.py`.

Hmm, at first I wasn't sure about that since you can still have multiple versions on the branch, but actually we should maybe even remove the file entirely so you can't accidentally commit from the wrong branch using the wrong default values...
I can confirm that @junrao's suggestion addresses this problem, but I'm not sure sure if there are better options. It does seem weird that the HW is on an old segment...
Agreed, it only makes sense for that tool to be used from trunk.

@hachikuji One option would be to go with @junrao's option and double-commit that to 0.9.0 and file a separate JIRA for considering the callback logic to keep the HW always on the latest segment. Thoughts?
@ijuma Yeah, that may work. Would be nice to get @becketqin's thoughts first though.
LGTM
I see. We can optimize a little by having a separate impl. If you think it is worth doing so, then ok.
cc @hachikuji

I agree with @ijuma that the new behavior is a bit too "automagical" and possibly un-intuitive. This change also means that the order of listeners in the configuration is suddenly meaningful and must be consistent across brokers or weird stuff will happen. 

I think the current behavior (with your recent patch) of either choosing plaintext or failing with validation is better.
@jjkoshy @auradkar Thanks for the review. I have updated the patch to address your comments.
LGTM

@becketqin As I understand, from looking at the code, the reason is so that users don't have to handle `ApiExceptions` from both `Future.get` and `send` depending on the implementation detail of whether we have done the call in the foreground or a background thread.
@MayureshGharat @becketqin The JIRA for this PR has 0.9.0.1 as the "Fix Version". If that is still the plan, then it would help if Guozhang's questions were addressed.
@gwenshap @ijuma I agree, depending on the order probably isn't great. I will close this.
The web-site still has the old version. Somebody needs to re-publish it.

@vahidhashemian If the topic deletion is disabled the topic will never be deleted with or without this patch and the delete topic path will never be cleared. This patch is intended to specifically handle the issue Jun mentioned in Kafka-3175. This patch in addition to handling kafka-3175 issue also clears the delete topic path. In either case if delete topic is disabled, it should show up with the --list OR --describe in kafka-topics command.

General question (since this code will go into Kafka project, and I don't know its policy): What about unit tests, e.g. for the equality semantics of `KeyValue`, which includes verifying `equals` and `hashCode`?  Typically, I'd always use unit tests to ensure that e.g. `equals` is symmetric, transitive, reflexive, and consistent (and that it should work if its argument is null).
`count` change looks good to me.
@ewencp @gwenshap Would you have time to review this?
@ewencp @gwenshap @ijuma Would you have time to review this?

cc @junrao @becketqin @ijuma 

This is a follow-up to #688 which fixes the case when there are is only one replica in ISR.
It would be good to double-commit to 0.9.0 as this causes build failures in some cases.
LGTM and fixed the problem on my machine.

@ijuma, @hachikuji Thanks a lot for your comments! I addressed them. Please take a look at KafkaProducer.send() method -- I tried to move intercepted record and callback out  per @ijuma suggestion. I think it looks better now. Please let me know if you have more comments.

Like @junrao said in #688, I wonder if we should only compare message offset in `precedes` (as it used to be). And maybe we should rename it to `messageOffsetPrecedes` to make it unambiguous.

If we do that, then I think we also have to change the following in `Partition.maybeIncrementLeaderHW` to also check the `offsetOnOlderSegment` (to restore Becket's fix):

`if(oldHighWatermark.precedes(newHighWatermark)) {`

It would also be good to add a comment above Jason's change with some of Jun's explanation:

"The problem that I am seeing is that when there is only 1 replica in ISR, the only time that we will update HW is when a new message is appended. So, if no new message is appended and we roll a log segment, HW will stay on the old segment. Now, if a new fetch request comes in with log end offset, log.fetch() will return the new segment in LogOffsetMetadata. Then, in DelayedFetch.tryComplete(), since the fetch offset is not on the same segment as HW (even though offset is the same), we will complete the fetch request immediately and therefore incorrectly ignore max wait time."

Finally, a new JIRA for changing it so that HW moves to the new segment.

Thoughts?
LGTM. Thanks for the fixes! Merged to trunk.

@ewencp

This PR says 

```
Closed with unmerged commits
This pull request is closed, but the wushujames:KAFKA-3216 branch has unmerged commits.
```

But Github shows that it has been merged. https://github.com/apache/kafka/commit/4fd60c6120dc4330deb7317360c835b04bc6cb9a

I guess the PR is wrong then? I can go ahead and delete my branch?

@wushujames, that message is due to the fact that the merge script creates a new commit with a few modifications, so GitHub thinks the branch wasn't merged (even though it really was). You can safely delete it, yes.
LGTM
Thanks for the patch. LGTM
Minor style things aside, looks fine.

@ijuma @gwenshap mind taking a look. I have added reasoning behind adding hadoop-core dependency. I am open to suggestion, if that can be avoided somehow. Without changing APIs, which seems not essential for default authorizer, I could not find a better way to pass requesting user's info to authorizer. Suggestions are welcome.

I don't think the Hadoop behavior is desirable (we probably want "nobody" if a user is not authenticated with Kerberos, not the OS user), and I'm definitely not a fan of this dependency.

system.username is definitely not desirable since its an environment variable and completely insecure. 
Since Hadoop manages to figure out the current principal (and so does kinit), I assume it is doable. Why not take a look at the Hadoop code and see how its done? 
Then we can also separate the behavior we need from behavior that is specific to Hadoop (use of OS name, specific format for Kerberos principals, etc)

LGTM.

Can you do a followup JIRA to review whether accepting empty strings is ever the right behavior? 
I'd like to keep our tools consistent and my guess is that all of them should fail on empty values.
LGTM. I had a tiny suggestion about the docs, but this can be improved later.
@ijuma Thanks for the review. I updated the test code.

Agreed with @gwenshap. In terms of the API changes to the Authorizer, do you mean adding a `Session` to every method related to ACLs so that the `Authorizer` can decide whether the principal can view and modify ACLs? If this is important, we should consider ways of doing it in a compatible manner (or, as a last resort, we could consider an incompatible change for 0.10.0.0 if it's easy for users to adapt their `Authorizer` implementations).
@granthenke Thanks for the suggestion. I did not want to assume anything on the first try, but if it is acceptable to assume a max value for partition count I'd be happy to update the pull request.
@vahidhashemian I would be interested in thoughts from others.
@ijuma This is the jira/pr related to #896
I thought PartitionState contains a leader value specifically so we won't need to make assumptions on order of replicas?

I think 249 characters and 99,999 partitions is a good solution. 
We need to document this as a limitation, but it sounds acceptable to me.
LGTM
@gwenshap Good point...let me look what going on there and report back

@gwenshap I thought that too, but @granthenke said there were test failures in #896 when the server started using the Java classes. It could be that the tests are wrong or that it was working accidentally because small immutable sets (up to 4 elements) in Scala maintain ordering.

Sounds good to me. With 249 characters for topic name we can actually have 100,000 partitions (since partition ids start from 0). I'll try to find the right place in the documentation to mention this limitation.
LGTM.

@gwenshap @ijuma It looks like the actual required behavior is correct. The test failure was due to replicas that did not match the same order. The change in #896 can definitely impact the order from what it was, but its being handled correctly by Kafka. I will close this and update the test in my original PR and leave replicas as a Set.
Awesome, thanks for checking this Grant.
@ijuma Updated this PR to fix the tests, and migrate UpdateMetadata.
